content.description: Go when it has been dry for a while, since it is like bouldering in a crypt.
content.location: As for exact location, you'll find it if only just to say you did it.

content.description: Walk to either side of the bridge and campus to the center support via the edge 2 feet below to top of the bridge. Rest in the center on the support, then campus to the finish on the other side.
content.location: Varisty Bridge located near Mackey Auditorium and next to McKenna Languages building on CU campus.

content.description:
WARNING: it is illegal and dangerous to climb routes on CU campus. Any climbing is undertaken at the climber's own risk.

This tower is a committing free solo on solid brick. The stone juts out from the building a decent couple inches, allowing for consistently bomber pinches and crimps the whole way up. Top out onto one of two small ledges to shake out before the downclimb (nets on the top prevent taking the stairs down from the inside). Don't blindly throw a hand onto the white ledge near the top - electrically charged wire is present to keep birds away.

The two part crux consists of keeping your head together as throngs of Snapchat-thirsty college students pool at the base while still moving fast enough to be off before campus police arrive. An inconspicuous moonlit ascent might be in good taste.

Featured in the film

Real Rock An Urban Climbing Experience

, releasing May 2019.
content.protection: A cam or large tricam could theoretically fit in some of the larger gaps between bricks, but at that point...what are you doing with your life?
content.location: This is found on the Humanities Building at the University of Colorado, Boulder. The east and the south sides of the tower are equally difficult.

content.description:
This is the most aesthetic line on the western face of Norlin Library. On each side of the main walk in you will see that the furthest pillars are close to the wall creating splitter chimneys that go up for about 3 stories. We reached the summit thinking we had reached virgin territory, but the names of a few others had been written on the summit block. It doesn't get much better than this! After further inquiry we learned that this route had been a standard in the 1960's by students at CU such as Bob Culp Front Range climbing legend. "If you were a climber you had to do it. I didn't like to or want to, but I did it too."

Featured in the film:

Real Rock an Urban Climbing Experience

coming May 2019.
content.protection: Solo, make sure you can down chimney or sling a friend, two can go at this at one time!
content.location: This is on Norlin Library on the west side main entrance on the pillars.

content.description: Climb the west side of Duane Physics (up to the west side of the overpass) up onto the roof.
content.location: This ascends Duane Physics. Descend by downclimbing or if you are lucky the roof door could be open and the stairs are a viable option.

content.description:
WARNING: it is illegal and dangerous to climb routes on CU campus. Any climbing is undertaken at the climber's own risk.

This problem is an excellent intro to CU campus brick. It climbs ~30 feet up to a balcony wherein one can (theoretically) walk off. The bricks jut out enough to give consistent crimps and pinches to an easy topout.

Hint: be prepared to downclimb - once on the balcony, we were denied access into the building because we weren't members of the prominent "upper division language studies" class.
content.protection: You can sew this baby up with 1s and 2s... just kidding.
content.location: It is on the East side of Eaton Humanities Building.

content.description: The routes here at CU are gaining in notoriety, Alex Honnold even came through to check out the stone and hit a few 'new' routes to further push the sport in our CU community.
content.location: This one is located on Balch Fieldhouse.
